author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Here’s why you need bottled water during a hurricane or tropical storm.
description: Powerful storms such as Hurricane Ida can cause power outages or damage public water systems.
content: Having an ample supply of clean water is a top priority during extreme weather like Hurricane Ida, which can disrupt normal water systems in several ways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier and Steven Erlanger
title: E.U. Set to Propose Travel Restrictions on U.S. Visitors
description: Two officials from the bloc said that starting Monday, the European Council would advise its member states to ban nonessential travel from the United States.
content: BRUSSELS — The European Union is set to advise member states that they should reintroduce travel restrictions for visitors from the United States, three E.U. officials said on Sunday, as coronavirus infections and hospitalizations have surged in the U.S. in recent weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Five Decades Later, Medicare Might Cover Dental Care
description: In the large budget bill now in Congress, supporters of the measure see a rare opportunity to advance a popular policy.
content: Tens of millions of older Americans who cannot afford dental care — with severe consequences for their overall health, what they eat and even when they smile — may soon get help as Democrats maneuver to add dental benefits to Medicare for the first time in its history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Shawn Hubler
title: What Voters Should Know About the Newsom Recall
description: Here’s everything you need to know to vote in the California gubernatorial recall election on Sept. 14.
content: The two questions Californians have been asked are simple: Should Gov. Gavin Newsom be removed from his job? And if so, who should take his place?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Zucchino
title: U.S. Conducts Drone Strike in Kabul and Winds Down Airlift as Deadline Nears
description: The strike eliminated what U.S. officials called an imminent terrorist threat. With the military evacuation of Afghans over,   the United States and others say they will still get people out.
content: A U.S. drone strike on Sunday destroyed an explosives-laden vehicle that the Pentagon said posed an imminent threat to Afghanistan’s main airport, as the massive airlift of Afghans fleeing Taliban rule shut down just two days before the scheduled final withdrawal of American forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: Morgan Stickney’s Race Against the Clock
description: Stickney, who endured first one amputation and then another, has put off surgery to chase a world record. After years of pain, she is closer to it than ever.
content: Four minutes 40 seconds and change. That is the time marker, the destination, the magnet drawing Morgan Stickney ever closer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Some Afghans say that enemies of the Taliban have begun to disappear.
description: As American troops rush to complete their withdrawal by President Biden’s Tuesday deadline, many Afghans are afraid that reprisals from the country’s new rulers will soon follow.
content: As American troops rush to complete their withdrawal by President Biden’s Tuesday deadline, many Afghans are afraid that reprisals from the country’s new rulers will soon follow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: 98 Countries Pledge to Accept Afghans After U.S. Military Departs
description: A joint statement from the United States and other countries said that they had “received assurances from the Taliban” that people with travel documents showing they were clear to enter any of those countries could safely depart.
content: WASHINGTON — The United States and 97 other countries said on Sunday that they would continue to take in people fleeing Afghanistan after the American military departs this week and had secured an agreement with the Taliban to allow safe passage for those who are leaving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Afghanistan, Florida, U.S. Open: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katy Reckdahl, J. David Goodman and Chelsea Brasted
title: Hurricane Ida, a Powerful Category 4 Storm, Batters Louisiana
description: White-capped waves appeared on the Mississippi River as winds uprooted trees, tore roofs from buildings and knocked out power for hundreds of thousands across the state.
content: NEW ORLEANS — Hurricane Ida howled into Louisiana on Sunday with powerful winds and dangerously high storm surges, lashing coastal communities, battering New Orleans and putting the city’s system for resisting catastrophic flooding to its biggest test since Hurricane Katrina.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Ida Strengthened Quickly Into a Monster. Here’s How.
description: Climate change plays a role in the rapid intensification of storms, and in Ida’s case, other factors worked as well to ramp up winds in a matter of hours.
content: Hurricane Ida, which struck the Louisiana coast on Sunday with winds of 150 miles an hour, gained power faster more than most storms. Because of climate change, such rapid strengthening is happening more often as hurricanes pick up more energy from ocean water that is warmer than before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $450,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: At Least One Dead as Tropical Storm Nora Lashes Mexico With Heavy Rain
description: The storm, which was downgraded from a hurricane, battered western Mexico with rain and was also blamed for at least two injuries in Jalisco State.
content: Tropical Storm Nora was downgraded from a hurricane on Sunday, a day after it formed, as it battered the western coast of Mexico and left at least one person dead, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden Receives Bodies of Soldiers Killed in Kabul Bombing
description: The president’s first trip in office to witness the transfer of remains was a reminder of the toll of the Afghanistan war, and of his unique relationship with it.
content: DOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Del. — A gray C-17 transport plane landed in Delaware shortly after 8 a.m. on Sunday. It carried the remains of 11 Marines, a Navy medic and an Army staff sergeant, who collectively could be the last Americans to die in the war in Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Drone strikes in Afghanistan.
content: After a bombing at the Kabul airport killed about 170 civilians and 13 American service members, the U.S. struck back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: Tropical Storm Julian Forms in the Atlantic
description: Julian, the 10th named storm of the 2021 Atlantic hurricane season, was expected to weaken and dissipate, forecasters said.
content: Tropical Storm Julian formed in the Atlantic on Sunday, becoming the 10th named storm of the 2021 Atlantic hurricane season, forecasters said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dennis B. Ross
title: Stop the Doomsaying. U.S. Credibility Will Weather Afghanistan.
description: To understand the implications of America’s withdrawal from Afghanistan, look to history.
content: This essay has been updated to reflect recent events.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Two Frozen Margaritas Later, We Agreed to Do It Again in a Month’
description: Catching the ferry after dinner and drinks, one way to see the sights and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Don Poynter, Who Made Toilets Talk and Golf Balls Walk, Dies at 96
description: His line of novelty items was wide-ranging. Jayne Mansfield posed for him so that he could make a shapely, sexy hot-water bottle.
content: Some of Don Poynter’s creations, it must be admitted, had a certain whoopee cushion quality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: U.S. diplomats are unlikely to stay in Afghanistan after troops leave.
description: The U.S. mission to Afghanistan will likely open in a country elsewhere in the region.
content: The United States is unlikely to keep diplomats in Afghanistan after the U.S. military departs on Tuesday, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said on Sunday, ending a 20-year mission of one of the largest American embassies in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: When the Truth Gets Twisted by a Lie
description: Through one employee of Dominion Voting Systems, a Times Magazine article examines the damage that false accusations can inflict.
content: As Susan Dominus, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine, approached her reporting for an article on the attacks on Dominion Voting Systems, a business that supplies election technology, she wanted to tell the story of one of the Dominion employees who was being vilified by supporters of President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 29, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Aug. 29, 2021.
content: An article last Sunday about Anne Bredin and JF Brandon’s wedding misstated when the bride’s family farmhouse was built in New Ipswich, N.H. It was built in the 1840s, not 100 years ago, which was when the bride’s maternal great-grandparents moved into the farmhouse. The article also misidentified the church where the bride’s parents were married. Her parents were married at the New Ipswich Congregational Church, not the Temple Congregational Church in Temple, N.H., where the couple were married.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katy Reckdahl and Chelsea Brasted
title: Some who stayed to ride out the storm are having second thoughts.
description: NEW ORLEANS — As storm-force winds and rainfall reached the New Orleans area on Sunday morning, knocking out power in some places and making highway travel dangerous, it was already too late to leave. Still, some people in the city were second-guessing their decision to stay.
content: NEW ORLEANS — As storm-force winds and rainfall reached the New Orleans area on Sunday morning, knocking out power in some places and making highway travel dangerous, it was already too late to leave. Still, some people in the city were second-guessing their decision to stay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: Delta Introduces a New Kind of Fee
description: As companies navigate vaccine requirements, a high-profile Silicon Valley trial is set to begin.
content: On Monday, the Food and Drug Administration granted full approval to Pfizer-BioNTech’s coronavirus vaccine for people 16 and older, kicking off a new wave of company vaccine mandates. Delta Air Lines announced a new approach to encouraging, rather than requiring, employees to take the vaccine: Starting Nov. 1, unvaccinated workers will have to pay an additional $200 per month to remain on the company’s health care plan. It’s unclear how effective the policy will be. Studies of employer wellness programs that promote healthy behavior, such as quitting smoking, by offering rewards or imposing penalties have shown little effect on employee health. But employees may respond differently to a program focused on vaccination, which doesn’t require a long-term behavior change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: As Washington Stews, State Legislatures Increasingly Shape American Politics
description: From voting rights to the culture wars, state legislatures controlled by Republicans are playing a role well beyond their own state borders.
content: With the release of the 2020 census last month, the drawing of legislative districts that could in large part determine control of Congress for the next decade heads to the nation’s state legislatures, the heart of Republican political power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt, David Zucchino, Najim Rahim and Thomas Kaplan
title: The U.S. strikes vehicle loaded with explosives in Kabul.
description: The possibility of civilian casualties was being investigated. The strike came hours after President Biden had warned of another possible terrorist attack.
content: A U.S. military drone strike blew up a vehicle laden with explosives in Kabul on Sunday, a Defense Department official said, as the immense effort to airlift U.S. citizens and Afghan allies fleeing the Taliban neared its conclusion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Can Novak Djokovic Be Invincible Again?
description: For months, the Serbian champion was unbeatable at the sport’s biggest tournaments. Then came the Olympics.
content: For months and months this year, at the most important tennis tournaments, it seemed as if Novak Djokovic was invincible, as if he simply could not be beaten.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Ron DeSantis, How Many Covid Deaths Are Enough?
description: Florida's governor is allowing you to choose death so that he can have a greater political life.
content: Republican politics have become oppositional politics: Deny the science, demean the media, own the libs. Conservatives are less defined by what they are for than by what they are against.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: How a Runner Turned a Nightmare Into a Great Olympic Moment
description: Falling on the Olympic stage is an unthinkable scenario for any athlete. Isaiah Jewett turned it into something else entirely.
content: For every sweat-soaked victory on the track at the Olympic Stadium in Tokyo, there were a lot of hopes dashed  in a single misstep.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Jentleson
title: When Will Biden Join the Fight for Voting Rights?
description: It's impossible to conclude that the president has been pulling out all the stops to defend voting rights.
content: Don’t look now, but the Senate is quietly becoming what it used to be: an institution ruled by a simple majority. At least, for certain kinds of legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A Lineup of Color Made History, Even if It Felt ‘Routine’
description: Fifty years ago, the Pittsburgh Pirates started a game using only Black and Latino players. It was a first in the National or the American League, and it still manages to stand out.
content: Roberto Clemente won two championships with the Pittsburgh Pirates, one when he was young and the other near the end of his brief life. For the first, in 1960, everyone else on the World Series roster was white, except for two teammates at the end of the bench. The second roster, in 1971, was much different.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset
title: When the New Covid Surge Struck, Mississippi Was Uniquely Unprepared
description: Poverty and politics have left the state with fewer doctors and nurses than it needs and hospitals on the brink of shutdown.
content: JACKSON, Miss. — On the ground floor of a parking garage at the University of Mississippi Medical Center, there are coronavirus patients where the cars should be — about 20 of them on any given day, laid up in air-conditioned tents and cared for by a team of medical personnel from a Christian charity group. Another garage nearby has been transformed into a staging area for a monoclonal antibody clinic for Covid-19 patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: American University of Afghanistan students and relatives trying to flee were sent home.
description: After seven hours of waiting for clearance to enter the airport gates and driving around the city, the group met a dead end: Evacuations were permanently called off.
content: Hundreds of students, their relatives and staff of American University of Afghanistan gathered at a safe house on Sunday and boarded buses in what was supposed to be a final attempt at evacuation on U.S. military flights, the students said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat and Tariro Mzezewa
title: Meteorologists were amazed by how fast Ida strengthened.
description: The storm had evolved swiftly from a worrisome disturbance to possibly the most devastating to strike Louisiana since Hurricane Katrina.
content: As Hurricane Ida closed in on the Louisiana coast on Sunday morning, meteorologists were stunned to watch the storm strengthen so quickly.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘How Long Can We Live?’
description: New research is intensifying the life span debate — with profound implications for the future of the planet.
content: Jeanne Calment lived her entire life in the South of France. She filled her days with leisurely pursuits, enjoying a glass of port, a cigarette and some chocolate nearly every day. In 1997, Ms. Calment died. She was 122.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Review: ‘Laetitia,’ a French True-Crime Gem, Comes to HBO
description: The Oscar-winning documentarian Jean-Xavier De Lestrade turns to fiction to tell a story of grisly murder in western France.
content: The French director Jean-Xavier de Lestrade won an Oscar in 2002 for “Murder on a Sunday Morning,” about a Black teenager wrongly accused of a killing in Florida, and a Peabody in 2006 for “The Staircase,” his influential series about a sensational murder trial in North Carolina. In the United States, he has solid credentials as a maker of crime documentaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
title: ‘What Will Happen to Me?’ An Uncertain Future Awaits Afghans Who Fled
description: Tens of thousands clambered onto evacuation planes bound for Qatar. Many are now in limbo in overflowing processing centers, fearful of what comes next.
content: AL UDEID AIR BASE, Qatar — Walking down the tarmac of the American military air base around 2 a.m. recently, the Afghan woman lunged for a handgun strapped to an American airman’s leg. As service members rushed to restrain her, she shrieked and thrashed — determined to kill herself. Then, she crumpled into a ball and sobbed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronica Penney
title: What We Know About Climate Change and Hurricanes
description: Scientists are confident that the warming of the planet is changing the way storms behave. Here’s how.
content: Hurricane Ida intensified overnight, becoming a Category 4 storm over the course of just a few hours. The rapid increase in strength raises questions about how much climate change is affecting hurricanes in the Atlantic Ocean. While researchers can’t say for sure whether human-caused climate change will mean longer or more active hurricane seasons in the future, there is broad agreement on one thing: Global warming is changing storms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Norimitsu Onishi
title: For France, American Vines Still Mean Sour Grapes
description: French authorities have tried to outlaw hardy American hybrids for 87 years. But climate change and the natural wine movement are giving renegade winemakers a lift.
content: BEAUMONT, France — The vines were once demonized for causing madness and blindness, and had been banned decades ago. The French authorities, brandishing money and sanctions, nearly wiped them out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Rasgon
title: Palestinians Finally Have Vaccines. But Will People Take Them?
description: For months, the Palestinian authorities struggled to get doses. Now they have the shots, but disinformation and conspiracy theories have led to widespread hesitancy.
content: BETHLEHEM, West Bank — Since the coronavirus first emerged in the occupied West Bank, Suha Gadeon has worn her mask assiduously, avoided mingling with friends and declined to host family members or attend public gatherings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Strikes Explosive-Laden Vehicle in Kabul
description: The drone strike came after a warning from President Biden that another terrorist attack at the Afghan capital’s airport was “highly likely.”
content: WASHINGTON — A U.S. military drone strike blew up a vehicle laden with explosives in Kabul on Sunday, Defense Department officials said, hours after President Biden had warned that another terrorist attack against the Afghan capital’s airport was “highly likely.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Everything’s Abuzz
description: Brooke Husic is super (vocalic).
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Some crossword constructors occupy a tight niche. They may be known for creating gorgeous, themeless puzzles with impeccable fill, like Robyn Weintraub, the so-called “Queen of the Fridays.” Or they may be prolific producers of simple, satisfying Monday puzzles, like Lynn Lempel, “Queen of the Mondays.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: As the Taliban Tighten Their Grip, Fears of Retribution Grow
description: Taliban leaders have promised amnesty to Afghan officials and soldiers, but there are increasing reports of detentions, disappearances and even executions.
content: ISTANBUL — When Taliban troops seized control of the Afghan capital two weeks ago, the invading units made a beeline for two critical targets: the headquarters of the National Security Directorate and the Ministry of Communications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: Inside Politico’s Billion-Dollar Drama
description: From “son of” to mogul in his own right: Robert Allbritton just became the unlikeliest winner of the new media sweepstakes.
content: I was sitting in a bar next to John Harris, a former national editor of The Washington Post. It was late in 2006, and he was recruiting me for a new project, a superblog called The Politico. I was interested, but I had a few questions about the owner. I had never heard of Robert Allbritton and I asked if he’d be the kind of billionaire publisher who wanted to see his own column on the front page, or if he’d be the other kind of wealthy owner, a dilettante who gets quickly bored with his new plaything.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Monks Once Led Protests. Myanmar’s Coup Changed That.
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, August 29, 2021.
content: “As a monk I couldn’t kill them, so I decided to become a soldier. It’s like going down from heaven to hell. But I think it was necessary.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Katy Reckdahl and Chelsea Brasted
title: In New Orleans, Anxiously Watching the Levees As Hurricane Ida Arrives
description: The prospect of “another Katrina” has haunted New Orleans, and the rest of the nation.
content: NEW ORLEANS — As Hurricane Ida began violently tearing through South Louisiana on Sunday, Kelli Chandler was holed up in a windowless office, waiting and watching for the answer to a question that all of New Orleans was asking: Would the levees — the newer, stronger, more sophisticated levees — hold back the storm?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: Why Poetry Is So Crucial Right Now
description: It helps us pay attention to the things that matter.
content: This summer, on a lark, I took a course on poetry geared toward Christian leaders. Twelve of us met over Zoom to read poems and discuss the intersection of our faith, vocations and poetry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Storm surges can threaten lives and damage property.
description: Hurricane Ida was expected to create dangerous storm surges along the Louisiana and Mississippi coasts.
content: Hurricanes and tropical storms are defined by their powerful winds. But the storm surges they produce can often prove just as destructive in coastal communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liam Stack
title: Houses of worship struggle with fear of Delta’s rise within their congregations.
description: The variant’s spread came just as churches began welcoming back faithful.
content: The weekly rhythms of Catholic life have started to return at Our Lady of Lourdes in Harlem. The pews are packed on Sunday mornings, prayer groups meet after work and the collection plate is almost as full as it was before the coronavirus pandemic began.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Ed Asner, Emmy-Winning Star of ‘Lou Grant’ and ‘Up,’ Dies at 91
description: Best known as the gruff newsman he first played on “The Mary Tyler Moore Show,” he was also a busy character actor and a political activist.
content: Ed Asner, the burly character actor who won seven Emmy Awards — five of them for playing the same character, the gruff but lovable newsman Lou Grant, introduced on “The Mary Tyler Moore Show” — and later starred in film hits like “Up” and “Elf” — died on Sunday at his home in Tarzana, Calif. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Z. Lin and Paul E. Sax
title: Why J.&J. Vaccine Recipients Should Also Get Booster Shots
description: Health authorities shouldn't leave J&J vaccine recipients behind in booster recommendations
content: The Biden administration wants people who got the Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna mRNA vaccines to seek a “booster” shot several months after their second dose, if the Food and Drug Administration deems them safe and effective. (Third doses are already authorized for immune compromised people.) Notably absent from these announcements are what the 14 million U.S. residents who have received the one-shot Johnson & Johnson vaccine should do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley
title: Biden witnesses the return of service members killed in the Kabul airport bombing.
description: They include 11 Marines, a Navy medic and a member of the Army.
content: DOVER AIR FORCE BASE, Del. — President Biden landed in Delaware on Sunday morning to join the families of the 13 members of the U.S. military who were killed in a bombing last week in Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: How Did Deep Blue California Get Played by Recall-Happy Republicans?
description: It's not just Gavin Newsom’s problem. The state’s recall system is strange and troubling.
content: The subject line of a recent fund-raising email from Gavin Newsom, the politically embattled governor of California, reads like the wheedling apologia of a busted boyfriend: “Can I please have a chance to explain?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Louisiana Braces for Hurricane Ida
description: Louisiana residents rushed to evacuate or hunkered down with supplies ahead of Hurricane Ida. The Category 4 storm is one of the most powerful systems to hit the region since Hurricane Katrina, bringing life-threatening storm surge and winds.
content: Louisiana residents rushed to evacuate or hunkered down with supplies ahead of Hurricane Ida. The Category 4 storm is one of the most powerful systems to hit the region since Hurricane Katrina, bringing life-threatening storm surge and winds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Observes Return of Troops Killed in Kabul Bombing
description: President Biden joined the families of 13 U.S. service members killed in a bombing at the Kabul airport in Afghanistan last week, as their remains were brought to Dover Air Force Base in Delaware. The fallen included 11 Marines, a Navy medic and an Army member.
content: President Biden joined the families of 13 U.S. service members killed in a bombing at the Kabul airport in Afghanistan last week, as their remains were brought to Dover Air Force Base in Delaware. The fallen included 11 Marines, a Navy medic and an Army member.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Eaton, Kassie Bracken, Natalie Reneau and Ben Laffin
title: ‘I Won’t Go 20 Years Back in Time’: Young Afghan Women Speak Out
description: A boxer. A singer. A journalist. Three young women found success in Kabul, Afghanistan. When the Taliban took the city, their dreams and lives were shattered.
content: A boxer. A singer. A journalist. Three young women found success in Kabul, Afghanistan. When the Taliban took the city, their dreams and lives were shattered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Storyful
title: Hurricane Ida Makes Landfall in Louisiana as a Category 4
description: The powerful storm made landfall near Port Fourchon, La., on the 16th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, slamming the southeastern coast with dangerous winds and storm surge.
content: The powerful storm made landfall near Port Fourchon, La., on the 16th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina, slamming the southeastern coast with dangerous winds and storm surge.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Latin Mass and the Foes of Pope Francis
description: Readers discuss a conservative movement within the Catholic Church. Also: A doctor's family in the pandemic.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Start with a big Italian-inspired spread, then go casual later on with BLT tacos.
content: Hello there. It’s Sunday, which in Italy means taking the time to make the pasta-filled, multicourse, multigenerational family lunch known as il pranzo di domenica.
source.name: The New York Times
